radioLabels.0: The name or ID that you use when you log in.

Q3.prompt: Sally is creating a username for a game. All players in the game will be able to see her username. Which of the following information is safe to include in her username?

radioLabels.0: Her full name
radioLabels.1: Her favorite character’s name
radioLabels.2: Her parents’ names
radioLabels.3: Her school’s name

Anyone on the Internet can find out who she is. C is incorrect: Having her parents’ names is not safe for her and for them. Anyone on the internet can find out who they are. D is incorrect: Having her school’s name makes it easy to find out her location, her age, and her name.

Q4.prompt: Mary has a social media account to post about BTS (musical band). Someone she doesn’t know messages her and offers to help her make new posts for this account. What should Mary do?

radioLabels.0: Give them the account login information because it is coming from a fan who wants to help out!
radioLabels.1: Tell them that she isn’t looking for any help and that they should ask another account.
radioLabels.2: Make them promise that they won’t do anything bad to the account.
radioLabels.3: Ignore the message and tell a trusted adult about the request.

Q4.explanation: D is correct: Ignoring the message and telling a trusted adult will keep her safe. The adult will know how to handle it properly and keep her from interacting with the stranger. A is incorrect: The person may not even be a fan and can just want to steal her account and her information. B is incorrect: This puts other accounts at risk. This also starts an interaction with the stranger which could lead to something more dangerous. C is incorrect: The promise doesn’t mean anything and they can easily break the promise and steal the account and the information.

Q5.prompt: Tom plays League of Legends (online game) and meets someone on it. They are promising to put extra items into his account. Tom just needs to give them his username and password so they can buy the items for him. What should Tom do?

radioLabels.0: Give them his username and password.

radioLabels.2: Ignore them and report the account.
radioLabels.3: Give them his username and password and then change his password later.

Q5.explanation: C is correct: Tom should not interact with someone he doesn't know on the internet, especially if they appear to be a scammer. Reporting the account keeps him and other people safe. A is incorrect: This can cause Tom to lose his account and any information connected to him. B is incorrect: Tom is still giving out his information. The other person could also give fake information. D is incorrect: Tom is still giving out his information. The stranger could change it before Tom changes it. The stranger also will have access to his information and steal the account.

radioLabels.0: Breaking news is urgent news that everybody should share with others right away.
radioLabels.1: Breaking news reports an event that has just happened or is currently happening.
radioLabels.2: Breaking news is fake news which are often clickbaits.
radioLabels.3: All of the above.

Q1.explanation: B is correct: Breaking news is information being reported about an event that has just happened or is currently occurring. A is incorrect: Breaking news may be urgent and deserve people’s attention, but we should not share it until we have enough information to confirm that the news is true. C is incorrect: Breaking news can be true or false information, we need to fact check to make sure the information is true.

radioLabels.0: Finding out whether the information you see in news stories is true.
radioLabels.1: Deciding whether a news story has biased opinions.
radioLabels.2: Checking with friends whether a news story is worth sharing.
radioLabels.3: All of the above.

Q2.explanation: A is correct: Fact checking is verifying the information you see in news stories. B is incorrect: Fact checking is about determining whether the information is true or false, not whether it is a fact or an opinion. C is incorrect: When doing fact checking, we should search for reliable information from reliable sources instead of simply checking with friends.

Q3.prompt: Which of the following actions should you take when trying to decide whether a breaking news article is accurate?

radioLabels.0: Find where or from whom the author got the information in the article.
radioLabels.1: Read the article and see whether this article is a news piece or an opinion piece.
radioLabels.2: Search online and see if there are other sources reporting this news.
radioLabels.3: All of the above.

Q3.explanation: A is correct: When we do fact checking on a breaking news article, we should check the source of information of that article to see if it comes from reliable sources. B is correct: To decide whether an article is trustworthy or not, we need to read the whole article and see whether it’s a news piece (something that actually happened) or simply the author’s opinions on something that happened, since opinions can be inaccurate. C is also correct: It’s also important to search online and find other reliable sources that confirm the same story.

Q4.prompt: Imagine that you see a breaking news article with the title, "New scientific evidence proves that eating more ice cream leads to cancer." The message looks trustworthy, but you're not sure. What should you do next?

radioLabels.0: Share this article with friends so they can find out more about this article.
radioLabels.1: Flag this article.
radioLabels.2: Search online to see if other trustworthy websites also reported the same news.
radioLabels.3: Check your friends’ Facebook to see if anyone else is sharing the same news.

Q4.explanation: C is correct: It is the correct way for fact checking. A is incorrect: We shouldn’t share breaking news with anyone before we fact check to make sure that the news is trustworthy. B is incorrect: If we found that the news is indeed trustworthy after fact checking, we shouldn’t flag the article and report it as false information. D is incorrect: Checking with friends to decide whether a news article is trustworthy is not recommended, because friends may not have the correct information. In other words, friends are not the most reliable source for fact checking.

Q5.prompt: Imagine that you see the following message in your social media: "Recent COVID vaccines caused heart attack. Please stop getting vaccines and share this news immediately". You feel it would be important to share the message. Is it OK to share it?

radioLabels.0: It's OK to share the message because it says, "Please share immediately."
radioLabels.1: It's OK to share the message because it looks official and you want others to protect themselves from the side effects of vaccines.
radioLabels.2: It's NOT OK to share the message because you're not sure it's true.
radioLabels.3: It's NOT OK to share the message because it’s safer to wait till more people share it first.

Q5.explanation: C is correct: If you are not sure if the news is true or not, never share it. A and B are incorrect: Before we share any news on social media, be sure to fact check to make sure the information is trustworthy so that you won’t spread false information. If you are not sure if the news is true or not, never share it. Even if the message looks urgent and looks official, it might still be fake news. D is incorrect: Even if a lot of people share the news on social media, it doesn’t guarantee the information is true. Always double check with other reliable sources to make sure the information is trustworthy.

radioLabels.0: True

radioLabels.0: True
radioLabels.1: False
radioLabels.2: I don’t know.

Q4.prompt: Which of the following people can be considered an upstander?

radioLabels.0: A person who sees a cyberbullying incident.
radioLabels.1: A person who bullies another person.
radioLabels.2: The person being bullied.
radioLabels.3: A person who confronts the bully.

Q4.explanation: D is correct: An upstander is someone who acts against the bully. A is incorrect: An upstander has to be someone who takes action after seeing an incident. B is incorrect: Upstanders act against the bully. C is incorrect: The person being bullied is considered a target or the victim of cyberbullying.

Q5.prompt: On Instagram, Michael keeps on making fun of Sarah in his stories. Because those stories are deleted after a while, it is hard to flag them or reply to them. What could you do to be an upstander?

radioLabels.0: Nothing, because the stories have been deleted.
radioLabels.1: You can post a story to make fun of Michael on your own Instagram page.
radioLabels.2: You can delete Michael’s story. You just have to find the right button.
radioLabels.3: You should tell a trusted adult about Michael’s behavior.

Q5.explanation: D is correct: Telling a trusted adult can be a safe way to take action and be an upstander. A is incorrect: Even though it is deleted, other people may have already seen the story or have screenshots of it. B is incorrect: If you post a story to make fun of Michael, you would be participating in cyberbullying. Upstanders do not bully other people in return. C is incorrect: You are unable to delete someone else’s story.

Q2.prompt: If you come across articles that are proven to be fake news, what you should NOT do?

radioLabels.0: Flag it.
radioLabels.1: Share it.
radioLabels.2: Report it.
radioLabels.3: Dislike it.

Q2.explanation: B is correct: You should not share articles that are proven to be fake news, as you would be spreading false information. A is incorrect: You should flag fake news articles as this will help admins of the site review the site and potentially take it down. C is incorrect: You should report fake news articles since that may result in it being taken down from the site. Q3.prompt: What should you do when trying to decide whether a news article is trustworthy?

radioLabels.0: Share the article on social media before reading it.
radioLabels.1: Read the article and try to fact-check the information in the article.
radioLabels.2: Trust that the writer of the article is telling the truth.
radioLabels.3: Ignore the article if you think the author might be biased.

C is incorrect: You should not merely trust articles to be credible and trustworthy. Q4.prompt: Which of the following is a clue that something might be clickbait?

radioLabels.0: It cites credible sources in the title.
radioLabels.1: It tries to shock you by using language like "You Won't Believe This"!
radioLabels.2: It is about a celebrity or a popular topic.
radioLabels.3: It is written by a famous journalist.

Often, the headline will try to make you curious and lure you like bait to click on it. A is incorrect: Credible sources are believable and trustworthy, so it is likely not clickbait. C is incorrect: Not all articles regarding celebrities or popular topics are clickbait. D is incorrect: An article being written by a famous journalist doesn’t automatically make it clickbait.

Q5.prompt: Lea wants to find expert-recommended diets for weight loss online. radioLabels.2: Share this article on Facebook and ask her friends to check it out.

Q5.explanation: A is correct: Lea should report the article because there are clear signs that it is fake news such as the fake website and the web address ending in 'com.co.' B is incorrect: The suspicious web address makes it clear that it is fake news, so Lea should not click into the article. C is incorrect: You should not share a suspicious article on your social media accounts. You would potentially be sharing false information with your friends. D is incorrect: Commenting on the article is not a good idea, as fake replies can be created. You should check other credible sites to fact-check instead.

A es incorrecta: no debes compartir artículos en tus cuentas de redes sociales antes de determinar si son confiables. C es incorrecta: no debes simplemente confiar en que los artículos sean creíbles. D es incorrecta: ignorar artículos que parezcan sesgados limitará tus fuentes de información, por lo que es mejor verificar la fuente y los hechos en lugar de simplemente ignorarlas.

Q4.prompt: ¿Cuál de las siguientes es una pista de que algo podría ser un clickbait??

radioLabels.0: Contiene citas confiables en el texto.
radioLabels.1: Intenta sorprenderte usando un lenguaje como ¡"No lo creerás"!
radioLabels.2: Es sobre una celebridad o algún tema popular.
radioLabels.3: Ha sido escrito por un famoso periodista.

C es incorrecta: no todos los artículos sobre celebridades o temas populares son clickbait. D es incorrecta: un artículo escrito por un periodista famoso no lo convierte automáticamente en un clickbait.

Q5.prompt: Leslie quiere encontrar dietas en línea recomendadas por expertos para bajar de peso. Buscó en Facebook y encontró un artículo titulado "Seis dietas sorprendentes que te ayudarán a perder 5 kilos en UNA semana, según expertos en salud del sitio web healthtips666.com.co". ¿Qué le aconsejarías que hiciera?

radioLabels.0: Reportar el artículo, presenta señales de que es fake news.
radioLabels.1: Hacer clic en el artículo y revisar si ha sido escrito por reales especialistas en salud.
radioLabels.2: Compartir el artículo en Facebook y pedirle a sus amigos que lo vean
radioLabels.3: Escribir un comentario para saber si alguien ha intentado alguna dieta.

Q5.explanation: A es correcta: Leslie debería denunciar el artículo porque hay signos claros de que se trata de una fake news, como por ejemplo, el sitio web es falso y la dirección web que termina en 'com.co'. B es incorrecta: la dirección web es sospechosa y deja claro que se trata de una fake news, por lo que Leslie no debería hacer clic en el artículo. C es incorrecta: no debes compartir un artículo sospechoso en tus cuentas de redes sociales. Potencialmente estarías compartiendo información falsa con tus amigos. D es incorrecta: Comentar el artículo no es una buena idea, ya que se pueden crear respuestas falsas. En su lugar, deberías consultar otros sitios creíbles para verificar los hechos.

Q1.prompt: ¿Cuál de las siguientes opciones es una sensación de alerta roja?

radioLabels.0: Sentirse satisfecho/a
radioLabels.1: Sentirse incómodo/a

radioLabels.3: Sentirse cansado y con sueño

Q1.explanation: B es correcta: Sentirse incómodo/a es una señal de la sensación de alerta roja. A es incorrecta: Sentirse satisfecho/a no está relacionado con la sensación de alerta roja. C es incorrecta: Sentirse animado/a no está relacionado con la sensación de alerta roja. D es incorrecta: Sentirse cansado y con sueño no está relacionado con la sensación de alerta roja.

radioLabels.0: Desconectarte de las redes y llamar a un amigo/a para ponerse al día
radioLabels.1: Desconectarte de las redes e ir a jugar básquetbol
radioLabels.2: Tener hobbies que no tienen nada que ver con estar en línea
radioLabels.3: Todas las anteriores

Q2.explanation: D es correcta: A es correcta: Desconectarte de las redes y llamar a tus amigos puede ayudarte a equilibrar el uso de los medios con otras actividades que disfrutas. C también es correcta: Para no pasar demasiado tiempo en línea y para no crear un desequilibrio, es importante tener hobbies que no sean en línea.

Q3.prompt: Cuando Ximena ve que su amiga Veronica sube una foto de un viaje divertido que tomó con su mejor amiga, ¿qué sensación de alerta roja podrá sentir Ximena?

radioLabels.0: Satisfacción
radioLabels.1: Emoción
radioLabels.2: Celos
radioLabels.3: Curiosidad

Q4.prompt: ¿Cuál de las siguientes acciones podría ayudar a Ximena a sentirse mejor acerca del viaje que sus amigas tomaron sin que ella supiera?

radioLabels.0: Quejarse en las redes sociales
radioLabels.1: Dejar de hablar con sus amigas en persona y en las redes sociales
radioLabels.2: Irse de viaje con otra amiga y compartirlo en las redes sociales para que ellas también se sientan celosas
radioLabels.3: Tomar una pausa de las redes sociales para calmarse y luego compartir sus sentimientos con sus amigas en un momento privado

Q4.explanation: D es correcta: Tomar una pausa de las redes sociales podría ayudarle a pensar en cómo se siente y que puede hacer para sentirse mejor. A es incorrecta: Como las redes sociales son públicas, quejarse de ello podría causar más malentendidos entre Ximena y sus amigas. B es incorrecta: Dejar de hablarle a sus amigas no es buena idea, ya que Ximena no está abordando sus sensaciones de alerta roja. C es incorrecta: Querer que otros tengan una sensación de alerta roja no es amable, así que no es buena idea publicar fotos de un viaje con otra amiga solo con ese propósito.

radioLabels.0: Desconectarse de las redes y pasar el rato con su familia
radioLabels.1: Permanecer en las redes sociales y fijarse si sus amigas suben más fotos
radioLabels.2: Salir a caminar
radioLabels.3: Llamar a su primo/a para ponerse al día

Q5.explanation: B es correcta: Permanecer en las redes sociales no es una buena idea, ya que puede generar más sensaciones de alerta roja. A es incorrecta: Pasar el rato con su familia puede ser una actividad agradable para Andrea y la puede ayudar a distraerse de los posts en Facebook. C es incorrecta: Salir a caminar es una buena idea, ya que puede resetear la mente de Andrea mientras hace una pausa de las redes sociales. D es incorrecta: Llamar su primo/a es una buena opción, ya que le permite descansar de las redes sociales y tener un buen equilibrio.

Q1.prompt: ¿Cuál de las siguientes opciones es una señal de que estás pasando demasiado tiempo usando las redes sociales?

radioLabels.0: Estableces cuántos minutos vas a estar en las redes sociales.
radioLabels.1: Usas tus redes sociales para compartir recursos y actividades divertidas con tus amigo/as.
radioLabels.2: Revisas tus redes sociales todo el tiempo, incluso cuando necesitas concentrarte en tu tarea.
radioLabels.3: Apagas las notificaciónes en tu teléfono cuando necesitas concentrarte en tu tarea.

Q1.explanation: C es correcto: Cuando te distraen de tus tareas importantes, las redes sociales pueden ocupar demasiado tiempo. A es incorrecta: Establecer la cantidad de minutos que vas estar en las redes sociales te ayudará a manejar mejor la cantidad de tiempo que pasas en las redes sociales. B es incorrecta: Usando las redes sociales para compartir recursos y actividades divertidas con tus amigo/as es una forma saludable de usar las redes sociales. D es incorrecta: Desactivar las notificaciones cuando necesites concentrarte en la tarea evitará que pases demasiado tiempo en las redes sociales.

Q2.prompt: ¿Qué hacen los ciclos de retroalimentación de las redes sociales?

radioLabels.0: Te ayuda a controlar cuánto tiempo pasas en las redes sociales.
radioLabels.1: Está relacionado con los recordatorios que configuras en los ajustes.
radioLabels.2: Te da placer cuando alguien responde a tus publicaciones.
radioLabels.3: Te da placer cuando aprendes algo nuevo en línea.

Q2.explanation: C es correcto: Los ciclos de retroalimentación de las redes sociales te hacen sentir placer cuando recibes un "like" o un comentario, lo que te hace revisar tus cuentas de redes sociales una y otra vez. A es incorrecta: Los ciclos de retroalimentación de las redes sociales hacen que permanezcas en las redes sociales incluso más tiempo de lo que pretendías. B y D son incorrectos: Tanto los recordatorios como el deseo de aprender cosas nuevas pueden hacer que revises tus cuentas de redes sociales, pero los ciclos de retroalimentación de las redes sociales están relacionados con las respuestas (como un "like" o comentarios) de otras personas que te dan placer y te hacen revisar tus cuentas de redes sociales más.

Q3.prompt: Laura es una fan de las Chivas. Ella usa sus redes sociales para recibir actualizaciones sobre juegos y jugadores. Las actualizaciones y notificaciones son infinitas y la hacen sentir como si se pudiera perder algo si no está en línea. ¿Cuál de las siguientes opciones le ayudaría a Laura a crear un uso más equilibrado de las redes sociales?

radioLabels.0: Podría dejar de usar las redes sociales.
radioLabels.1: Podría usar la configuración para aumentar el número de notificaciones.
radioLabels.2: Podría usar la configuración de notificaciones para limitar la cantidad de notificaciones diarias.
radioLabels.3: Podría seguir a un equipo de fútbol diferente en las redes sociales.

Q3.explanation: C es correcto: Limitar la cantidad de notificaciones diarias evitaría que Laura busque actualizaciones con tanta frecuencia. A es incorrecta: Dejar las redes sociales no sería más equilibrado porque Laura no usaría las redes sociales en absoluto. B es incorrecta: Aumentar la cantidad de notificaciones haría que Laura revisara aún más su teléfono. D es incorrecta: Seguir a un equipo de fútbol diferente no ayudaría a Laura a controlar su uso general de las redes sociales. Ella buscaría actualizaciones tanto como antes.

Q4.prompt: Gerardo es muy activo en sus redes sociales y recibe muchos comentarios en sus publicaciones. Para responder a todos los comentarios, ha comenzado a rechazar invitaciones de amigos cercanos para salir a jugar fútbol, su deporte favorito. ¿Cómo puede Gerardo administrar mejor su uso de las redes sociales para un estilo de vida equilibrado?

radioLabels.0: No hay nada que Gerardo pueda hacer al respecto porque necesita responder a sus amigos en línea.
radioLabels.1: Puede pedirle a sus amigos del equipo de fútbol que lo ayuden con las respuestas.
radioLabels.2: Puede responderle a sus amigos en línea a altas horas de la noche, incluso si eso significa perder algo de tiempo para dormir.
radioLabels.3: Puede decidir no responderle a todos inmediatamente.

Q4.explanation: D es correcto: Gerardo puede jugar al fútbol con sus amigos y luego responder a los comentarios en otro momento. A es incorrecta: Gerardo no tiene que responder inmediatamente a sus amigos en línea. Él puede revisar sus comentarios más tarde. B es incorrecta: Preguntarles a sus amigos del equipo de fútbol los distraería a él y a sus amigos de jugar fútbol. C es incorrecta: Gerardo no necesita responder a todos los comentarios al mismo tiempo antes de acostarse. Puede extender sus respuestas para un estilo de vida más equilibrado.

Q5.prompt: Lo primero que hace Lucero por la mañana es buscar notificaciones en sus redes sociales. Cuando no recibe muchas reacciones a sus publicaciones, se entristece y siente que a la gente realmente no le cae bien. Como amigo/a de Lucero, ¿qué consejo le darías para apoyar su bienestar?

radioLabels.0: Solo sigue publicando cosas, estoy seguro/a de que lo harás bien con el tiempo.
radioLabels.1: Borra tu última publicación, la gente no está interesada en lo que has estado haciendo.
radioLabels.2: No lo tomes personalmente. Si a las personas no les gusta una publicación, no significa que no les gustes tu.
radioLabels.3: Mantente conectada todo el día y obtendrás más reacciones a tus publicaciones.

Q5.explanation: C es correcto: No recibir muchas reacciones no significa que Lucero no le caiga bien a la gente. Es imposible que a las personas les gusten cada publicación que vean. A es incorrecta: Animar a Lucero a publicar más puede hacer que se sienta más decepcionada si aún no recibe reacciones de los demás. B es incorrecta: Decirle a Lucero que borre su publicación puede hacerla sentir que a la gente no le agrada y que se sienta mal con ella misma. D es incorrecta: Estar en las redes sociales todo el día no es saludable. Desarrollaría un hábito desequilibrado en las redes sociales.

Q1.prompt: When someone tries to trick you into sharing your password or personal information, that’s called _____.

radioLabels.0: Cyberbullying
radioLabels.1: Encryption
radioLabels.2: 2-step verification
radioLabels.3: Phishing

Q1.explanation: D is correct: Phishing is when someone tries to trick you into sharing important private information. A is incorrect: Cyberbullying is when a person posts or shares negative information about another person online. B is incorrect: Encryption has to do with protecting your information with a password. C is incorrect: 2-step verification is when you add an extra layer of security to protect your account when you log-in.

Q2.prompt: What should you do if you have fallen for a phishing scam?

radioLabels.0: Change your password to the website immediately.
radioLabels.1: Report to the website about the phishing scam.
radioLabels.2: Tell a trusted adult so that they can help you.
radioLabels.3: All of the above.

Q2.explanation: D is correct: A, B, and C are all actions you should take if you fall for a phishing scam.

Q3.prompt: You see a post on social media that says "CLICK HERE to receive a free trial for our newest online multiplayer game! FREE subscription to everyone who clicks!" What should you do?

radioLabels.0: Click on the link.
radioLabels.1: Click on the link and then send the link to your friends.
radioLabels.2: Ask your gamer friend if this is real or not.
radioLabels.3: Ignore the post.

Q3.explanation: D is correct: Ignoring the post is a good idea to protect your information from scammers. A is incorrect: It is not a good idea to click on a suspicious post. Scammers often offer free items or giveaways to trick people into clicking. B is incorrect: Sharing a suspicious link that may be a scam is not a good idea, since your friends may get phished or scammed. C is incorrect: Your gamer friend may not be the best person to ask. A trusted adult would be a better person to ask advice from.

Q4.prompt: You see a contest that reads "Win $10,000 instantly! Click this link to sign up!" You click on the link, and the website asks for your name, address, and email to enter the contest. What should you do?

radioLabels.0: Put in fake personal information.
radioLabels.1: Don’t give any personal information. Because someone could steal your information to create a fake identity pretending to be you.
radioLabels.2: Put in your personal information, because you’ll have the chance to win a lot of money.
radioLabels.3: Post the link on your Facebook page and ask your friend to sign up for the contest.

Q4.explanation: B is correct: Not giving away any personal information is the safest option since your personal information can be stolen by scammers. A is incorrect: Putting in fake information is not safe as well since they could be tracking your location and the website may have unsafe links. C is incorrect: It is not safe to give away your personal information as someone can steal your identity. D is incorrect: Sharing the link to your facebook page is not a good idea since your friends can also have their information stolen.

Q5.prompt: Your friend Jane sends you an email asking you to send her your address. But somehow the email doesn’t sound like Jane at all. Which of the following actions is unsafe?

radioLabels.0: Ask Jane whether she actually sent the email.
radioLabels.1: Ask a trusted adult what to do next.
radioLabels.2: Don’t worry too much, just give her your address.
radioLabels.3: Don’t respond to the email.

Q5.explanation: C is correct: It is not safe to give her your information, scammers can pretend to be your friend and even send emails from Jane’s account. A is incorrect: It is a good idea to confirm with Jane. B is incorrect: A trusted adult can give you helpful advice. D is incorrect: Responding can lead to dangerous situations where your information may be stolen.

Q1.prompt: Cuando alguien intenta engañarte para que compartas tu contraseña o información personal, eso se llama _____.

radioLabels.0: Cyberbullying
radioLabels.1: Cifrado
radioLabels.2: Verificación en 2 pasos
radioLabels.3: Phishing

Q1.explanation: D es correcta: Phishing es cuando alguien intenta engañarte para que compartas tu información privada. A es incorrecta: Cyberbullying es cuando una persona realiza o comparte posts con información negativa sobre otra persona en línea. B es incorrecta: El cifrado tiene que ver con proteger tu información con una contraseña. C es incorrecta:Verificación en 2 pasos es cuando agregas un paso adicional de seguridad para proteger tu cuenta cuando inicies sesión.

Q2.prompt: ¿Qué debes hacer si caes en una estafa de phishing?

radioLabels.0: Inmediatamente cambiar la contraseña.
radioLabels.1: Reportar al sitio web la estafa de phishing.
radioLabels.2: Decirle a un adulto de confianza para que te ayude
radioLabels.3: Todas las anteriores.

Q2.explanation: D es correcta: A, B y C son acciones que puedes hacer si caes en una estafa de phishing.

Q3.prompt: Si ves un post en redes sociales que dice"¡CLIC AQUÍ para recibir una prueba gratuita de nuestro nuevo juego multijugador en línea! ¡Suscripción GRATUITA para todos los que hagan clic!" ¿Qué debes hacer?

radioLabels.0: Hacer clic en el link.
radioLabels.1: Hacer clic en el link y luego enviarle el link a tus amigos.
radioLabels.2: Preguntarle a tu amigo gamer si es cierto o no.
radioLabels.3: Ignorar el post

Q3.explanation: D es correcta: Ignorar el post es una buena idea para poder proteger tu información de los estafadores. A es incorrecta: No es buena idea hacer clic en post sospechosos. Los estafadores usualmente ofrecen items gratis o giveaways para engañar a las personas a que hagan clic. B es incorrecta: Compartir un link sospechoso que puede ser una estafa no es una buena idea, tus amigos pueden ser estafados. C es incorrecta: Tu amigo gamer no es la persona más ideal para preguntarle. Es mejor recibir un consejo de un adulto de confianza.

Q4.prompt: Ves un concurso que dice "¡Gana $10,000 al instante! ¡Haz clic en este enlace para registrarte!" Haces clic en el enlace y el sitio web te pide tu nombre, dirección y correo electrónico para participar en el concurso. ¿Qué debes hacer?

radioLabels.0: Colocar información personal falsa.
radioLabels.1: No dar tu información personal. Una persona puede robar tu información y crear una identidad falsa para hacerse pasar por ti.
radioLabels.2: Poner tu información personal porque así tendrás la chance de poder ganar el dinero.
radioLabels.3: Poner el link en tu Facebook y pedirle a tu amigo que se inscriba.

Q4.explanation: B es correcta: No dar ninguna información personal es la opción más segura, ya que los estafadores pueden robar tu información personal. A es incorrecta: Poner información falsa tampoco es seguro pues podrían estar rastreando tu ubicación y el sitio web puede tener enlaces inseguros. C es incorrecta: No es seguro dar tu información personal, ya que alguien puede robar tu identidad. D es incorrecto: Compartir el enlace a tu página de facebook no es una buena idea porque a tus amigos también les pueden robar la información.

Q5.prompt: Tu amiga Mariella te envía un correo preguntándote por tu dirección. Pero algo del correo pareciera que no es realmente un mensaje de Mariella. ¿Cuál de las siguientes acciones es riesgosa?

radioLabels.0: Preguntarle a Mariella si ella realmente envío el correo.
radioLabels.1: Preguntarle a un adulto de confianza qué puedes hacer.
radioLabels.2: Darle tu dirección sin preocupación.
radioLabels.3: No responder el correo.

Q5.explanation: C es correcta: No es seguro darle tu información, los estafadores pueden fingir ser sus amigos e incluso enviar correos electrónicos desde la cuenta de Mariella. A es incorrecta: Es una buena idea confirmarlo con Mariella. B es incorrecta: Un adulto de confianza puede dar un consejo útil. D es incorrecta: Responder puede conducir a situaciones peligrosas en las que su información puede ser robada.

Q1.prompt: Which of the following is true about social media audiences?

radioLabels.0: Multiple accounts can help you manage what different people will see about you.
radioLabels.1: Once you open an account, you always have full control over who sees your posts.
radioLabels.2: You have no control over your social media audience no matter what you do.
radioLabels.3: Social media is for sharing, so you don’t have to worry about who will see your posts.

Q1.explanation: A is correct: People can have separate accounts for different types of content and audiences. B is incorrect: You do not always have full control over who sees your post, since other users can share your posts. C is incorrect: You can control who follows you on social media. However, you do not have full control over your social media audience. D is incorrect: Social media is for sharing, but private information should not be shared with everyone.

Q2.prompt: Why would some people want to create different social media accounts?

radioLabels.0: To interact with different types of groups such as friends, family, or people with similar interests.
radioLabels.1: To see and share specific types of content such as games, sports, books, etc.
radioLabels.2: To participate in online interactions without revealing their true identities.
radioLabels.3: All of the above.

Q2.explanation: D is correct: A, B, and C are all reasons to create different social media accounts. People would want different social media accounts to interact with different groups of people, have accounts for specific content, and to keep their identities anonymous.

Q3.prompt: What is true about anonymous accounts?

radioLabels.0: People can never find out who you are.
radioLabels.1: People can still find out who you are based on your posts.
radioLabels.2: It’s never a good idea to use an anonymous account.
radioLabels.3: It’s always a good idea to use an anonymous account.

Q3.explanation: B is correct: Even if you are anonymous, what you post may give clues to your identity. A is incorrect: Even if you are anonymous, people can find out who you are based on what you post or your friends on social media. C is incorrect: It can be a good idea to use an anonymous account to post specific content without revealing your identity. D is incorrect: It is not always a good idea to use an anonymous account in case you want an account to connect with your friends or family.

Q4.prompt: Olivia has noticed that her friend Laura is using an anonymous account to say mean things about their classmates. Which of the following actions should Olivia take?

radioLabels.0: Olivia should not say anything. This is Laura’s account after all.
radioLabels.1: She can tell Laura to only say mean things about people who are mean.
radioLabels.2: She can ask Laura to use her real account if she wants to say mean things about someone.
radioLabels.3: She can tell Laura that it’s not nice to post those comments even if she is using an anonymous account.

Q4.explanation: D is correct: Olivia should tell Laura that it is hurtful to comment or post mean things even from an anonymous account. A is incorrect: Olivia should ask Laura to never comment or post mean things. B is incorrect: Olivia can explain to Laura that it’s hurtful to say mean things about people, even if the people are mean. C is incorrect: Laura should not use any account to say mean things about people.

Q5.prompt: You are okay with your grandma sharing and tagging you in videos of you as a baby in her social media account. However, you are concerned that some friends may start making fun of you. A practical and responsible way to manage this issue would be:

radioLabels.0: Deleting your social media account.
radioLabels.1: Asking grandma to delete her account.
radioLabels.2: Telling grandma that you don’t like those videos.
radioLabels.3: Creating a private social media account for the family.

Q5.explanation: D is correct: You can create a separate account for family, so your family can still share content without your friends seeing. A is incorrect: If you delete your social media account, you won't be able to stay connected with your family and friends. B is incorrect: If you tell your grandma to delete her account, she might feel hurt and would not be able to share posts with others. C is incorrect: You could tell your grandma that you don’ t like when she shares those videos on her public account.

Q1.prompt: Where can you change what information is visible to other users and companies?

radioLabels.0: Direct messages
radioLabels.1: Privacy settings
radioLabels.2: Friend's page
radioLabels.3: You can't

Q1.explanation: B is correct: You can change what information is visible to other users and companies in privacy settings. A is incorrect: Direct messages are where you can talk to your friends. You cannot change what information is visible to other users and companies. C is incorrect: Your friend’s page has their information visible. Only your friend can change that information. D is incorrect: You can change what information is visible by using your privacy settings.

Q2.prompt: Jennie is reading Instagram’s privacy policy before signing up for an account. What should she ask herself when analyzing it?

radioLabels.0: What will be accessed or collected by Instagram?
radioLabels.1: What will be shared with other companies?
radioLabels.2: What could be known about me if I use Instagram?
radioLabels.3: All of the above.

Q2.explanation: D is correct: A, B, and C are part of the acronym ASK which is used when analyzing a privacy policy. These questions would help Jennie think about what will be accessed or collected by the company, what will be shared with other companies, and what could be known about her if she creates an account.

Q3.prompt: Irene’s brother posted a picture of her and tagged her in it. Irene doesn’t want her friends to see that picture when they go to her profile. What should Irene do?

radioLabels.0: Tell her friends to not look at her tagged pictures.
radioLabels.1: Edit her privacy settings so that tagged pictures do not show up on her profile.
radioLabels.2: Delete her account.
radioLabels.3: Ask her brother to never post pictures of her again.

Q3.explanation: B is correct: Irene can change what information is visible to others by editing her privacy settings. A is incorrect: This won’t have an effect on who will see the pictures. Her friends can still go to her profile and look at the pictures. C is incorrect: This is a dramatic measure for something that can be changed easily in the privacy settings. D is incorrect: If Irene is only concerned about her friends seeing the pictures, she can solve the issue by changing her privacy settings.

Q4.prompt: Jamie has a private social media account for friends and family. Someone she doesn’t know requests to follow her and messages her trying to get to know her. What should she do?

radioLabels.0: Delete the message but accept the follow request.
radioLabels.1: Follow them back and start chatting with them.
radioLabels.2: Do not accept the follow request and tell a trusted adult.
radioLabels.3: Message them and ask them who they are.

Q4.explanation: C is correct: She should not interact with that person because it could be dangerous. Telling a trusted adult will keep her safe and the adult can take actions to keep her safe. A is incorrect: Accepting the follow request will give the stranger access to her posts and information, which is unsafe. B is incorrect: It is not safe to interact with strangers. D is incorrect: It is not safe to interact with strangers.

Q5.prompt: Your friend asks you to join a social media site to communicate with each other. You read in their privacy policy that they sell your information to anyone and are not responsible for any consequences. What should you do?

radioLabels.0: Make the account anyways. What are the chances your information will be taken?
radioLabels.1: Make the account but don’t put anything personal on it.
radioLabels.2: Ask your friend about it.
radioLabels.3: Ask a trusted adult about the situation before making an account.

Q5.explanation: D is correct: A trusted adult can help you choose if creating the account is a good idea for you or not. A trusted adult can also read the privacy policy clearly and see if there is anything wrong. A is incorrect: The chances that your information will be taken is higher than you think. A small risk is still a risk and you should think it through first. B is incorrect: There is more information than what you input into it. Your email and your password is considered sensitive information. Your IP address could also be tracked. C is incorrect: Your friend might not know the dangers of the whole situation. Asking a trusted adult is the best option for an opinion.

Q1.prompt: ¿Dónde puede cambiar qué información es visible para otros usuarios y empresas?

radioLabels.0: Mensaje directo
radioLabels.1: Configuración de la privacidad
radioLabels.2: En el perfil de un amigo
radioLabels.3: No puedes

Q1.explanation: B es correcta: Puedes cambiar qué información es visible para otros usuarios y empresas en la configuración de privacidad. A es incorrecta: los mensajes directos son donde puedes hablar con tus amigos. En esa opción no puedes cambiar qué información es visible para otros usuarios y empresas. C es incorrecta: la página de tu amigo tiene su información visible. Solo tu amigo puede cambiar esa información. D es incorrecta: puedes cambiar qué información es visible en la configuración de privacidad.

Q2.prompt: Jenifer está leyendo la política de privacidad de Instagram antes de crear una cuenta. ¿Qué debería preguntarse a sí misma al analizarlo?

radioLabels.0: ¿A qué accederá o que información recopilará Instagram?
radioLabels.1: ¿Qué compartirá con otras empresas?
radioLabels.2: ¿Qué se podría saber de mí si uso Instagram?
radioLabels.3: Todas las anteriores

Q2.explanation: D es correcta: A, B y C son parte del acrónimo ASK que se utiliza al analizar una política de privacidad. Estas preguntas ayudarían a Jenifer a pensar sobre lo que la empresa accederá o recopilará, lo que se compartirá con otras empresas y lo que se podría saber sobre ella si crea una cuenta.

Q3.prompt: El hermano de Isabel publicó una foto de ella y la etiquetó. Ella no quiere que sus amigos vean esa foto cuando van a su perfil. ¿Qué debe hacer Isabel?

radioLabels.0: Decirle a sus amigos que no vean la foto etiquetada.
radioLabels.1: Editar la configuración de la privacidad para que la foto no se muestre en su perfil.
radioLabels.2: Eliminar su cuenta.
radioLabels.3: Pedirle a su hermano que no vuelva a poner una foto de ella

Q3.explanation: B es correcta: Isabel puede cambiar qué información es visible para los demás editando la configuración de la privacidad. A es incorrecta: esto no tendrá ningún efecto sobre quién verá las imágenes. Sus amigos todavía pueden ir a su perfil y ver las fotos. C es incorrecta: esta es una medida dramática para algo que se puede cambiar fácilmente en la configuración de la privacidad. D es incorrecta: si a Isabel solo le preocupa que sus amigos vean las imágenes, puede resolver el problema cambiando su configuración de la privacidad.

Q4.prompt: Jaime tiene una cuenta privada en las redes sociales para amigos y familiares. Alguien a quien no conoce solicita seguirlo y le envía un mensaje tratando de conversar con él. ¿Qué debería hacer él?

radioLabels.0: Eliminar el mensaje, pero aceptar la solicitud
radioLabels.1: Darle follow a la persona y contestar el mensaje.
radioLabels.2: No aceptar la solicitud y decirle a un adulto de confianza.
radioLabels.3: Responderle y preguntarle quién es

Q4.explanation: C es correcta: no se debe interactuar con un desconocido porque podría ser peligroso. Decírselo a un adulto de confianza lo mantendrá a salvo, pues el adulto puede tomar las medidas correspondientes. A es incorrecta: aceptar la solicitud le dará al desconocido acceso a sus publicaciones e información, lo cual no es seguro. B es incorrecta: no es seguro interactuar con desconocidos. D es incorrecta: no es seguro interactuar con desconocidos.

Q5.prompt: Tu amigo te pide que te unas a una nueva red social para que puedan conversar. Revisas la política de privacidad y lees que podrían vender tu información a cualquier persona y no son responsables de ninguna consecuencia. ¿Qué deberías hacer?

radioLabels.0: Crearme la cuenta de todos modos. ¿Cuáles son las posibilidades de que mi información sea tomada?
radioLabels.1: Crearme la cuenta, pero sin poner información personal sobre mi.
radioLabels.2: Preguntarle a mi amigo sobre eso
radioLabels.3: Preguntarle a un adulto de confianza antes de crearme la cuenta

Q5.explanation: D es correcta: un adulto de confianza puede ayudarte a elegir si crear la cuenta es una buena idea para ti o no. Un adulto de confianza también puede leer claramente la política de privacidad y ver si hay algún problema. A es incorrecta: las posibilidades de que se roben tu información son más altas de lo que piensas. Un pequeño riesgo sigue siendo un riesgo y debes pensarlo bien primero. B es incorrecta: hay más información de la que ingresaste. Tu correo electrónico y contraseña se consideran como información confidencial. Tu dirección IP también podría ser rastreada. C es incorrecta: es posible que tu amigo no conozca los peligros de toda la situación. Preguntar a un adulto de confianza es la mejor opción para obtener una opinión.

Q1.prompt: What type of information is NOT safe to share online with strangers?

radioLabels.0: Your favorite Minecraft characters.
radioLabels.1: Your pet’s name.
radioLabels.2: Your favorite ice-cream flavors.
radioLabels.3: Your home address or real name.

Q1.explanation: D is correct: Your home address and real name are private information and should not be shared with strangers. A, B and C are incorrect: Your favorite Minecraft characters, pet’s name, and favorite ice-cream flavors are safe to share with anyone because they are not private information.

Q2.prompt: Why is it risky to share private information online with strangers?

radioLabels.0: You don’t know what people will do with your information.
radioLabels.1: Some people may use your information to trick you.
radioLabels.2: Some people may use your information to spam you.
radioLabels.3: All of the above.

Q2.explanation: D is correct: A, B, and C are all reasons why sharing private information online with strangers is risky. You don’t know what people will do with information you share, and they may trick you or spam you.

Q3.prompt: How can you respond when someone you don’t know well and have not met in person asks you for private information?

radioLabels.0: Send the information in a direct message so others will not see it.
radioLabels.1: Ask to meet the person first.
radioLabels.2: Ignore the message and tell a trusted adult about the request.
radioLabels.3: Ask why the person wants to know.
radioLabels.4: Send the information and then tell a trusted adult about the request.

Q3.explanation: C is correct: Ignoring the message will prevent the person from gaining information from you. Tell a trusted adult, so they can assess the situation and decide how to proceed. A is incorrect: Sending the private information to the person you don’ t know that well may be risky because they may have bad intentions. B is incorrect: Sharing your location and meeting someone you don’ t know is dangerous. D is incorrect: The person may trick you into revealing your private information.You should not continue talking to them. E is incorrect: It’ s important to tell a trusted adult about the request before sharing any private information.

Q4.prompt: Sam is your online friend whom you have never met in person. You know a little about what she likes but nothing else. One day, Sam asks for your home address. Which of the following responses is the safest to use?

radioLabels.0: Sure. I’ll send it to you via email.
radioLabels.1: I will send it later today.
radioLabels.2: I will share my home address only after you send me yours.
radioLabels.3: I don’t share this type of information online.

Q4.explanation: D is correct: Since you have never met Sam in person, you should not share your home address or any other private information. A, B, and C are incorrect: It’s not safe to share your home address. You should be clear that you don’t share private information, so she will not keep asking you for it.

Q5.prompt: Your best friend is eager to talk about summer plans and has shared his phone number in a chat with the entire school. As his friend, what should you tell him?

radioLabels.0: I’ll share my number in the chat too so people can invite me for summer activities.
radioLabels.1: Please delete your message. It’s not safe to share your private information with people you don’t know.
radioLabels.2: How many people have replied to your message?
radioLabels.3: Great idea. Let’s ask everyone to share their phone numbers!

Q5.explanation: B is correct: Your friend should delete the message, so less people will see it. Sharing a phone number is not safe, and people may use it with bad intentions. A is incorrect: You should not share your number, and then tell your friend it’ s not safe to share private information with the entire school. C is incorrect: The number of replies is important to know how many people have your friend’ s number, but you should also tell your friend not to share their private information. D is incorrect: You should not encourage your friend to share private information. It is also dangerous for everyone to send their phone numbers in the group chat.

radioLabels.0: It means companies are collecting information about you and using it to show you ads for things that you like.
radioLabels.1: It means companies are making advertisements very entertaining.
radioLabels.2: It means advertisements shown on large billboards next to highways.
radioLabels.3: It is just another term for all advertisements on the Internet.

Q1.explanation: A is correct: Companies collect data (your visited sites, clicks, etc.) about you, so they can show you ads for things that they think you will like. B is incorrect: What is entertaining is different for each person, so companies must collect data to see what each person finds entertaining and what they might like. C is incorrect: Large billboards are not targeted advertisements. D is incorrect: Targeted advertisements refer to the specific advertisements that certain apps and sites show you, not all advertisements on the Internet.

Q2.prompt: Advertisements on social media are based on your preferences.

radioLabels.0: True
radioLabels.1: False
radioLabels.2: I don’t know.

Q2.explanation: A is correct: Advertisements on social media are based on data that companies have collected about you, to see what you might prefer.

Q3.prompt: Companies collect all sorts of data about you online to show you targeted advertisements, even though you may not realize it.

radioLabels.0: True
radioLabels.1: False
radioLabels.2: I don’t know.

Q3.explanation: A is correct: Companies want to show you ads of products you might like, so they collect data about you. But you may not realize your data is being collected such as your clicks on websites and apps.

Q4.prompt: What is a “sponsored” post on a social media site?

radioLabels.0: It is a post that is particularly interesting.
radioLabels.1: It is a post that has a lot of likes.
radioLabels.2: It is a post that is paid for by a company.
radioLabels.3: It is a post from a very popular user.

Q4.explanation: C is correct: Companies pay for “sponsored” posts on social media to advertise their product, but they look a lot like posts from the average person. A is incorrect: Posts can be interesting without being a sponsored post. B is incorrect: Social media influencers and celebrities can receive lots of likes on their posts even if the posts are not sponsored. D is incorrect: Not all sponsored posts are from very popular users.

Q5.prompt: Jeremy was looking for new shoes on an online shopping website yesterday. Today, he saw ads for the type of shoes he likes on his Facebook page. What could Jeremy do to prevent these ads from targeting him?

radioLabels.0: Look for different types of shoes online.
radioLabels.1: Turn off the cookies in his web browser.
radioLabels.2: Like the ads on his Facebook page.
radioLabels.3: Turn off his phone.

Q5.explanation: B is correct: Cookies are used to identify your device and track your behavior on websites. Turning off cookies in the web browser makes the companies unable to track your behaviors, so it may help prevent targeted advertisements. A is incorrect: Looking for different types of shoes may lead to more ads appearing on his Facebook page as his behavior may be tracked by cookies. C is incorrect: Liking ads may result in more targeted ads since likes may be tracked as part of data that companies collect. D is incorrect: Turning off his phone would help him to not see ads when the phone is off. But when Jeremy turns on his phone to use it, the ads will likely reappear.
